node.title: error: cannot convert 'std::vector<double>' to 'std::vector<MetaPhysicL::DualNumber<double, MetaPhysicL::SemiDynamicSparseNumberArray<double, long unsigned int, MetaPhysicL::NWrapper<53> >, true>, std::allocator<MetaPhysicL::DualNumber<double, MetaPhysicL::SemiDynamicSparseNumberArray<double, long unsigned int, MetaPhysicL::NWrapper<53> >, true> > >&'

node.bodyText:
Hello
You're trying to store a vector of AD number in a vector of reals.
We've disallowed this implicit conversion, you ll need to store in an ADRealvectorvalue
another way is to use the MetaPhysicL::raw_value(ADReal a) routine to convert each component of the vector
Guillaume

Nope. none of them works. error:
    _creep_strain[_qp].symmetricEigenvaluesEigenvectors(eigvals, eigvec);
      |                                                         ^~~~~~~
      |                                                         |
      |                                                         std::vector<double>

Makes me wonder if it is possible to obtain the eigenvector from that creep strain.

So eigvec is of the wrong type right?
What is the compiler saying for the type that it should be?
yeah this works. thanks @iyevugah @GiudGiud

node.title: Component thermal_expansion_coeff implementation

node.bodyText: Can't you follow ComputeCrystalPlasticityThermalEigenstrain if it doesn't already handle your use case?

Currently, we are going to use it for thermo-elastic problems in small strain, so not crystal plasticity and large strain mechanics. Also with this I want to get me feet wet in coding/understanding MOOSE for some of the future developments we have planned (temperature dependent orthotropic thermal_expansion and elasticity).. so I wanted to implement a relatively simple code.

I understand what you are trying to do. What I was suggesting is that you can write your code following the ComputeCrystalPlasticityThermalEigenstrain. All the operations you need are already done in the source code of that object.

Thanks a lot @hugary1995 for the suggestion, really appreciate it, and I looked at the code and as you mention it has all the requisite operations in the crystal plasticity large strain formulation.
I did manage to write a code that does for simple cubic systems, that seem to work. However, I inherited from ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain class. If you get a chance please let me know your thoughts about the approach.
Thanks again,
-Aritra
I think i meet the same problem, my method is use the fillFromInputVector
i directly pubilc computeEigenstrainBase, i think there should have more simple method.

And then modify computeQPEigenstrain (), yeah..that's an approach. I was thinking along those lines too, but then you would have to get temperature (material property) as well as the stress free temperature at each _qp.
That's why I wanted to inherit from ThermalExpansion class
I tested the above code and it seems to work for a preliminary case, where I have CTE_11 != CTE_22 != CTE_33 for a cubic geometry with linearly varying temperature field:
However, since I inherited from ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain which needs the required parameter thermal_expansion_coeff I had to provide that in the input file (i gave it 0).

I guess define the same name
'thermal_expansion_coeff' will slove this problem？Later i will try.

node.title: Question on [ComputeLagrangianStrain]
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSEers,
in the page of ComputeLagrangianStrain https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/materials/lagrangian/ComputeLagrangianStrain.html, there is the note reading"The strain calculator does not apply the eigenstrains to the deformation gradient, only the incremental and integrated strain measures."
So dose it mean for small strain, it's used to calculate eigenstrain from total strain as \epsilon = \epsilon_mech + \epsilon_eigen?
and for large kinematics, the eigen part like the thermal deformation gradient is not excluded from the total deformation gradient, as decomposed F=F^\theta F^mech? and what if the thermal part should be excluded?

So dose it mean for small strain, it's used to calculate eigenstrain from total strain as \epsilon = \epsilon_mech + \epsilon_eigen?

This is correct. The stress calculator computes stress as function of mechanical strain.

and for large kinematics, the eigen part like the thermal deformation gradient is not excluded from the total deformation gradient, as decomposed F=F^\theta F^mech? and what if the thermal part should be excluded?

No, for large kinematics the eigenstrains are also accounted for if you use one of the objectively integrated stress calculator, i.e. we advect a small stress-strain model to render it as a large deformation model.
However, if you use some hyperelastic material model and directly compute stress as a function of the deformation gradient, then indeed the eigenstrains are not being excluded. That is a missing capability in the new system.
Thanks @hugary1995

node.title: undefined reference to `MooseApp::restore(std::shared_ptr<Backup>, bool)`
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I've updated the conda moose environment and moose (git pull on branch next), but I'm now unable to install my application, because of the following error:
Linking Executable /import/heisenbug-dump/ulrich/myLibs/Tiger/tiger-opt...
/import/tegern-data/ulrich/MyLibs/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /import/heisenbug-dump/ulrich/myLibs/moose/modules/module_loader/lib/libmodule_loader_with_fp_tm_pf-opt.so: undefined reference to `MooseApp::restore(std::shared_ptr<Backup>, bool)'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status

Any idea?
Thanks in advance,
Thomas Ulrich

Hello
You ll need to:

save all your work (git commit -am if you're not sure)
go in the tiger/ folder
git clean -xfd
git submodule foreach git clean -xfd
then rebuild

there are some old compiled objects in the folders and they're messing with the linking
Guillaume

node.title: doubled AreaPostprocessor results
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I use AreaPostprocessor to set the proper 'flux_function' for PorousFlowSink BC.
The model contains a 50m(X)5m (Y)50m (Z) reservoir within the 100m100m100m cubic.
I set the PorousFlowSink BCs on both the inj_well (in green, 5m50m=250 m2) and pro_well (in blue, 5m50m=250 m2).
But the output of AreaPostprocessor is 500 m2, two times of actual area. But the volume of the reservoir is 125000 m3, and the area results of top and bottom boundaries are 1000 m2. These are correct.
Could you please help me with this?

Hello
this is a meshing issue most likely
Either:

two layers of sides are included in the sideset you re measuring the area of
sides in both directions (normal pointing both ways) are included in the sideset

both are problematic, and will force you to redo your mesh generation
You can also work with a ParsedGenerateSideset to restrict the sideset to what you want. Maybe indicating the included_sideset and included subdomains will be enough to restrict the sideset
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
thanks a lot! I use ParsedGenerateSideset and get the correct area of 250 m2.
Best regards,
J

node.title: Deformation issue
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I want to know in MOOSE how to output the deformation displacement caused by a single strain model like creep? I hope someone can answer my question. Thanks.

Hello
look for the variable disp_x in your output.
Are you wanting to see the field or sample some values?
Guillaume
Like if there is a deformation caused by thermal expansion and creep, How do I know how much deformation is caused by thermal expansion or creep alone?

Those are probably stored as strains.
Use show_material_properties in the Debug block to see if they are. And if so you can output material properties with an option in the Outputs block
You can only output strains separately. If you want, maybe you can find a way to integrate the strain and get the displacements from the strain. I do not believe we have that capability yet.
That's what I was thinking，thanks.

Maybe we should back up a little bit first: Do you want some measure of deformation that corresponds to the entire body, or at every point in the domain? In other words, do you need a single number or some field outputs?
At every point in the domain I suppose.
Or a specific point on the boundary.

That you won't be able to tell directly, and reason is simple: displacements are macroscopic observables and you can't decompose them according to constitutive relations.
I second @jiangwen84 's suggestion. If you really want to decompose some global measure you'll have to get the global measure by homogenizing your quantities of interest in the first place. For example, integrate strain_xx to get total displacement in the x direction, and since strain = elastic strain + creep strain + thermal strain, you can then integrate each of them to get their respective contributions.
I see，thanks.

node.title: self-creep does not effecate

node.bodyText:
what do you mean by "NOT WORKING"? does not converge? or you can not see only creep deformation?
You can output the strain either add a print statement in the computeStressFinalize function or output them in Paraview or PostProcessor.

the not working is when i close the ZrIrradiationCreep, the strain_xx is same to the condition that i use the ZrIrradiationCreep, but different with the condition that i use the PowerLawCreep.
the creep rate is same, for the model is unit Mpa
i output the _creep_strain_xx, but it zero. so it mean that the code is wrong?
adding more print statements to figure out which step is wrong.
i have solved! thanks!

node.title: Is it possible to overlap control drum mesh with reactor core lattice?
node.bodyText:
I am new to MOOSE and using the reactor module to mesh a control drum and hexagonal lattice reactor core. The reactor I am trying to model has already been developed and optimized by a previous student in SCALE. However, I am running into an issue creating the mesh with the reactor module because in the SCALE model, the control drum and hexagonal lattice overlap as seen below:

I can't find anything in the docs where you can delete sections of the hexagonal lattice and replace it with another mesh. I have created the model using the PatternedHexMeshGenerator to create the lattice and PeripheralRingMeshGenerator to create the control drum and combined them using XYDelaunayGenerator.

Is this even possible using the reactor module, or would I need to import a geometry meshed using a different software?
@miaoyinb

If the background region (the region outside the central circles) of the partial assembly meshes are the same material (block) as the peripheral region. You can use FlexiblePatternGenerator to do it.
If not, meshing it might still be possible but the process would be complex/non-trivial. We can discuss if needed.
The background region of the partial assembly meshes is the same block as the peripheral region, however, there is a duct on the hexagonal lattice with a different block. Would this be an issue?
Is the duct connected to the control drum?
The duct is around the hexagonal lattice structure for the fuel pin. The control drum does not have a duct.
As your control drum is overlapped with the hexagon structure. At the position of the overlapping, is the duct of the hexagon structure connected to the external surface of the control drum?
The current model in scale just has the duct disappear at the location of intersection, but it could be added or removed. Our design is not at that level of detail yet.

Whether the duct needs to be connected to the control drum or not would actually affect the complexity in meshing.
If they are not connected, you may use XYMeshLineCutter to cut a fraction of the hexagon structure and then use FlexiblePatternGenerator to fill the gap. Otherwise, I think a non-trivial use of ParsedCurveGenerator + XYDelaunayGenerator may be needed to take care of things.

node.title: Multicomponent phase-field simulations
node.bodyText: I am fairly new to phase-field simulations, but I wanted to try using them to explore liquid-liquid phase separations.  I did see some examples for multiphase models, but I am struggling a bit to implement a multi-component model.  I would like to simulate a system with 4 charged species (two positive and two negative) and solvent, and I was wondering what is the best way to ensure the concentrations of all species sum to 1, and ensure that charge neutrality is maintained.
@vprithiv just worked on this! Not with charged liquids though.

One way to ensure the concentrations of all species sum to 1 is to remove one concentration and substitute it by 1-sum(c_i). Another way would be to use the Lagrange Multiplier approach we have implemented.

I'd go farther and just have two variables: p and n, for the concentrations of one of the positive and one of the negative species.  Then the second positive species has concentration 0.5-p, the second negative 0.5-n.  (Assuming all charged species are singly-charged; the same trick works if some are doubly- or whatever but the numbers differ)

This is what I have been recently working on: simulating a two-phase flow using a combined Navier-Stokes and Cahn-Hilliard equations. I employed a single order parameter, which can take values of -1 or 1. The phase field was primarily used to track the interface between the two fluids. Material properties in the Navier-Stokes equations, namely density and viscosity, were defined as functions of the order parameter. If you are working on anything similar or find this information helpful, I can provide you with the relevant references.

@dschwen I did see the Lagrange Multiplier kernel, and I'll look into it more!  It might also help with the charge neutrality.  I was able to directly add the electrostatic penalty to the mixing energy for enforce charge neutrality in my simulations, but it does seem to be computationally costly, and so I was wondering if there was a more efficient way to impose constraints on the component concentrations.
If you have a good example of the lagrange multiplier being implemented somewhere I think that would help me a lot!

@vprithiv I am interested in implementing hydrodynamics into my phase field simulations, although currently I am more focused on the spinodal decomposition aspect of polyelectrolyte coacervates systems.  Still, I would love to read up more on coupling Navier-Stokes with Cahn-Hilliard!

I'd go farther and just have two variables: p and n, for the concentrations of one of the positive and one of the negative species. Then the second positive species has concentration 0.5-p, the second negative 0.5-n. (Assuming all charged species are singly-charged; the same trick works if some are doubly- or whatever but the numbers differ)

I will give it a shot!  I do have a significant amount of solvent in both phases, but perhaps I just need to rewrite the free energies of mixing.

These may help:
P Yue et al., Phase-field simulations of interfacial dynamics in viscoelastic fluids using finite elements with adaptive meshing
C Zhou et al., 3D phase-field simulations of interfacial dynamics in Newtonian and viscoelastic fluids

node.title: Citing the mooseframework documentation and images
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm currently writing up my DPhil thesis. I am referencing the mooseframework documentation as my project utilised the MOOSE code. For the web pages, I have gone with a traditional @online block like so:
@online{mooseframework-FeatureFloodCount-2023,
	author = {Idaho National Lab.},
	title = {FeatureFloodCount},
	url = {https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/FeatureFloodCount.html},
	urldate = {2023-09-11},
	year = {2023},
	bdsk-url-1 = {https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/FeatureFloodCount.html}}

However, when describing the FeatureFloodCount class:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/FeatureFloodCount.html
I was hoping to re-use the diagrams as a figure for the visual ease of describing what is going on.
Who would I need to ask for permission from to do this? Is this allowed at all?
Thank you, and all the best,
Matthew

Thank you for taking the time to reply, but that doesn't address my question. I am not citing the MOOSE codebase, what I am asking about is how to use the images in the MOOSE documentation in a PhD thesis. One cannot just copy and paste a picture or a plot or a photograph without permission. I am asking whose permission I would need to obtain to recreate the figure on the web page I linked explaining how the FeatureFloodCount class worked.

@permcody worked on this particular feature of the code.
He can grant you permission, or he will know who to contact.

Hi @MatthewWilliamNoble, I don't see any issues with you using my images. Please do! They originally appears in my PhD thesis, but it may be easier to cite them with one of the follow-on papers: https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00295450.2020.1843893
